The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

And Å¿urely I have many times wondered how thoÅ¿e men who are none of the learnedest, Å¿hould be able to draw Å¿uch a faction after them, and bewitch the minds of the people: for every one of theÅ¿e Presbyteriall Dictators is more eÅ¿teemed then the whole Church of God, they take upon them to teach their mother to give Å¿uck, the people have plucked out their owne eyes, and given to their teachers, being now able to Å¿ee nothing but through their spectacles, unto whom they doe aÅ¿cribe more then Papall Infallibility. And beÅ¿ides their forwardneÅ¿Å¿e to lead a faction, I have obÅ¿erved diverÅ¿e other meanes wherby they have wonne the affection of the people unto a generall liking of their cauÅ¿e; I. II. Their diligence in preaching, which yet in them is, rather the labour of the lungs, then of the brain, and (I thanke God)

To taxe the faults of men in chiefe place, and the preÅ¿ent government, which the multitude (being ever prone to innovation, and diÅ¿like of the preÅ¿ent Lawes) are apt to approve, as Nazianzen obÅ¿erved in his time, he is thought the holieÅ¿t man that can find moÅ¿t faults, and the greateÅ¿t zelot for the trueth, who is pleaÅ¿ed with nothing, but what proceeds from his owne deviÅ¿ing. Are not theÅ¿e they whom S. Peter deÅ¿cribes that Å¿hould ariÅ¿e In populo, II. Pet. 2. amongst the people, deÅ¿piÅ¿ers of governement, back-biters of them that are in dignity, Å¿peaking evill of thoÅ¿e things they know not, who promiÅ¿e unto themÅ¿elves liberty? That is the thing at which they ayme [liberty;] for howÅ¿oever they Å¿eeme to except only againÅ¿t our Lawes, yet the thing they would have, is a freedome from all Lawes, and that it may be lawfull for every man to apparrell Gods worÅ¿hip in what faÅ¿hion he pleaÅ¿eth, and to doe what Å¿eemeth good in his owne eyes, as though there were no King in IÅ¿rael: wherby they doe wonderfully pleaÅ¿e the factious people, Et hoc ipÅ¿o placere cupiunt, quod placere

They give unto the people both by their doctrine and example incouragement to commit two Å¿innes, whereunto of all others they are moÅ¿t inclined, VÅ¿ury and Sacriledge: VVherefore S. Iude deÅ¿cribing thoÅ¿e murmurers, & complainers whoÅ¿e mouths Å¿peake proud things, Å¿ayeth, ver. 16. They have mens perÅ¿ons in admiration becauÅ¿e of advantage, And that we may all know whom he meaneth, he addeth, ver. 19. TheÅ¿e are they that Å¿eparate themÅ¿elves. By whoÅ¿e divinity, men (as I Å¿ayd) have theÅ¿e two advantages, one that they may lend their money upon uÅ¿ury: Another that they may Å¿afely robbe God of his tythes, and devour all manner of holy things: This last was the ayme of Å¿ome Politicians in the kingdome of England, they Å¿et on diÅ¿contented men, to cry out againÅ¿t the governement of the Church, hoping by that meanes to prey upon BiÅ¿hoprickes and Cathedrall Churches, as they had done before upon the Abbeyes. V. This their Å¿now-ball of popularity hath gained no Å¿mall acceÅ¿Å¿e by their lying: They traduce thoÅ¿e who are not of their faction, as men either of Å¿candalous life, or
mainetayners of falÅ¿e doctrine, and Å¿uch as Å¿eeke to draw us backe agayne unto Popery: They tell the people of their owne victories in diÅ¿putations and conferences, how they have put others to Å¿ilence with the Å¿trength of their arguments, when indeed they have not Å¿poken one wiÅ¿e word: They boast of the inward teÅ¿timony of Gods Å¿pirit aÅ¿Å¿uring their conÅ¿ciences of the trueth of their doctrine. Ludov. Viv. de verit. fid. chriÅ¿t. l. 4. pag. 178. And this (as Å¿ayeth a learned writer) is TutiÅ¿simum mentiendi genus, The Å¿afeÅ¿t way of lying is for men to intitle God to their owne dreames. LaÅ¿tly, But the sp â¢ ciall meanes wherby they have advanced their faction, is by inÅ¿inuating into the weaker Å¿exe in whom there is leaÅ¿t ability of Iudgment. By this meanes the Serpent overcame mankind, he firÅ¿t tempted the woman, and by her Å¿educed Adam: By this meanes the PhiliÅ¿tines overcame SampÅ¿on, Iudg XIV. 18. They ploughed with his heifer and Å¿o found out his riddle. And this indeed hath beene the common practiÅ¿e of all haeretickes: Act XIII. 50. the Iewes Å¿tirred certaine devout & honorable women to reÅ¿iÅ¿t Paul. TheÅ¿e new Gospellers make uÅ¿e of Å¿uch inÅ¿truments to oppoÅ¿e the Church, and for the moÅ¿t part their ProÅ¿elytes

Now to Å¿earch a litle into the cauÅ¿e of this: BeÅ¿ides the weakeneÅ¿Å¿e of their Iudgement to diÅ¿cerne betweene truth and error, and the naturall inclination which is in women to pitty; two things especially make them in love with that religion, one, It is naturall unto the daughters of Eve to deÅ¿ire knowledge, and thoÅ¿e men puff them up with an opinion of Å¿cience, inabling them to prattle of matters of divinity, which they and their teachers underÅ¿tand much alike: InÅ¿omuch that albeit S. epigraph.q: But if he neglect to heare the Church; Let him bee unto thee as an heathen man, and a Publicane.

div.p: THESE are the words of our bleÅ¿Å¿ed Lord and Saviour IESVS CHRIST, Sect. I. containing a Direction unto the Church, for cenÅ¿uring her diÅ¿obedient children, and an injunction to all you who profeÅ¿Å¿e CHRIST, to take notice of her cenÅ¿ures, accounting no otherwayes of all thoÅ¿e who deÅ¿piÅ¿e her admonitions, then as of heathen men and Publicanes, If hee neglect to heare the Church, Let him bee unto thee as an heathen man, and a Publicane.

There is one word in the Text, Sect. 2. as it is expreÅ¿Å¿ed in the Olde TranÅ¿lation [alÅ¿o] which being a Relative, Å¿ends us backe to the words going before, to finde out the occaÅ¿ion of this Å¿peach. I finde that our Saviour in this Chapter, doth exhort his DiÅ¿ciples, and in them all ChriÅ¿tians, to a conÅ¿cionable care, of the Å¿alvation of their brethren, and that firÅ¿t, by giving no offence, whereby they may be Å¿candalized, Take heed that yee deÅ¿piÅ¿e not one of theÅ¿e little ones, ver. 10. and before, Woe unto that man by whom offence commeth. and Å¿econdly, by patient bearing of Å¿uch offences as come from them, and labouring to reÅ¿tore them that are fallen, and to bring them to repentance. ver. 15. If thy brother Å¿hall treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e againÅ¿t thee, &c. Where before I come to my Text, it will bee expedient that I inquire of foure things. 1. To whom our Saviour Å¿peaketh? to his DiÅ¿ciples. 2. Of whom? of a brother, If thy brother treÅ¿paÅ¿Å¿e. 3. Of what offences? If hee treÅ¿paÅ¿se againÅ¿t thee. 4. What is the rule preÅ¿cribed in this caÅ¿e? Goe and tell him his fault betweene him and thee. If he Å¿hall heare thee, thou hast gained thy brother. But if he will not heare thee, then take with thee one or two more, that in the mouth of two or three witneÅ¿Å¿es, every word may be eÅ¿tabliÅ¿hed. And if he Å¿hall neglect to heare them, tell it unto the Church.

I. Sect. 3. ChriÅ¿t Å¿peakes unto his DiÅ¿ciples, as may appeare by the whole diÅ¿courÅ¿e from the beginning of the Chapter, but he Å¿peakes not unto them as they are ApoÅ¿tles, and chiefe PaÅ¿tors in his
Church, but Å¿implie as they are DiÅ¿ciples, that is, ChriÅ¿tians; for all the followers of ChriÅ¿t were called DiÅ¿ciples, Ioh. VI. 66. The not diÅ¿tinguiÅ¿hing of theÅ¿e two, what was given in charge to the ApoÅ¿tles, as they were ApoÅ¿tles, and chiefe PaÅ¿tors; and what as they were ChriÅ¿tians, hath occaÅ¿ioned many miÅ¿priÅ¿ions. I will inÅ¿tance only, in two particulars. Our Saviour in the celebration of the Sacrament of the Supper, Å¿ayth to his DiÅ¿ciples, Drinke yee all of this: The PapiÅ¿ts underÅ¿tand this to bee Å¿poken to them, as they were ApoÅ¿tles, and MiniÅ¿ters of the Church, and Å¿o deny that the people have any right to the Cup. whereas it is evident, that in that firÅ¿t Supper, they did beare the perÅ¿on of Communicants, and Å¿o that benefit belongs to all ChriÅ¿tians.
